column4: it seems that when you boot up that your screen blanking kicks in immediately. Have you tried shutting down those settings in the BIOS?
I have not spotted any settings on screen blanking on boot, I havn't noticed any screen blanking when I boot
when you boot can you access anything?

Not sure what you mean, I can get into BIOS but I havn't spotted any options in there for screen blanking. When I boot into ubuntu I havn't noticed any problems with blanking, except this intermitant problem when the screen blanks and I wiggle my mouse to wake it up if i am reading
I read the URL you posted. It has to do with Power Manager. That may be a BIOS setting.
I ask this always to many who ask the same question you asked. Do you run a Dual Boot with Windows. If so check the Windows settings on Screen Management.
No I am only booting ubuntu on this computer
shut off power management in BIOS just to test this theory. Also Sleep Mode. You can always reset it back.
is it a USB mouse? Have you tried to exchange the mouse for another mouse just to see if the mouse is a bad one?
what you explained from a Technical viewpoint, you should check first the obvious, i.e., the mouse and if it is USB plug it into another USB port.

I dont think its a mouse issue, but I will try anyway it does seem that its exhibiting the exact problem on the blog when it dims I hit the 50ms race with my wiggle to brighten it up, the timer doesn't reset and it proceeds to turn it off down the line
is it a USB or PS/2 mouse?
I have a usb mouse but I was using the mousepad, I think its connected to PS/2
also are you running a laptop?
yes
if you remove the PS/2 mouse does the problem go away?
NEVER remove any PS/2 mouse while the laptop is running. Power down first then remove.
well I dont have a physical PS/2 mouse connector, I have no idea what my touch pad connects to internally though
in Windows for example there are power settings for screen saver and power management and sleep mode. I believe that Ubuntu has the very same settings. They control the BIOS at bootup.
ok well thanks for the help with this I'l live with it for the time being :)

which brings us to another line of reasoning. If your CMOS battery is dead or weak, then, your computer time frame is off. If you check the date when you re-boot and see if the time and date is correct only after the computer has been sitting for a while like you said, you may find that could be your answer.
